examples.text: Siinä on virran vettä ja varmaan jo uve-avannoitakin.
examples.english: It has got the water from the stream and probably already holes opening under the ice.

words.etymology_text: Internationalism (see English uvarovite). Contains the suffix -iitti.

examples.text:
Edellisten päivien leudot ilmat olivat vaikuttaneet sen, että Volgan jää oli syvän uve-veden vallassa – –
The mild temperature of the previous days had had the effect of the ice on the Volga now being covered in deep water from the holes in it – –
examples.ref: 1859, August Ahlqvist, Muistelmia matkoilta Venäjällä vuosina 1854-1858, Viides kirja

glosses: A hole in the ice of a lake or other body of water, created by water flowing from below the ice.

words.etymology_text:
table
Ultimately derived from Proto-Uralic *uwa (“stream”) with the suffix + -e, either an irregular retention form (compare vuo, vuotaa) or based on a stem re-loaned from early Samic (compare old Southern Sami uwe (“stream”)).

examples.text: Kannusti uvetta urho, ajoi tapparan teriä, tuli Ruijan rantamalle, missä hyrskyi aalto hyinen, meri selkeä sinerti.
examples.ref: 1903, Eino Leino, Helkavirsiä I, Pyhä Yrjänä

categories: Omitted translation in the main namespace

words.etymology_text:
table
From Proto-Finnic *ubeh. Cognate with Ingrian uve, Karelian uveh, Livvi uveh, Ludian ubeh and Veps ubeh.

categories: Finnish terms derived from Late Latin

forms.form: Rare. Only used with substantive adjectives.

words.etymology_text: From Late Latin ūvula (“little grape”), diminutive of Latin ūva (“grape”).
